newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay bourse declares two brokers as defaulters.
newsitem.headline: Bombay bourse declares two brokers as defaulters.

text.p: The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) said it declared two member-brokers of the exchange as defaulters after they failed to honour commitments.
"(The two brokers) have failed to meet their obligations to the exchange and to discharge their liabilities," the BSE said in a statement issued on Tuesday night.
The two brokers are Mukesh Mansukhlal Kothari and Yogesh Mehta.
"All clients of the above mentioned defaulter members are requested to file their claims, if any, within six months," the BSE statement said.
On Monday, the National Stock Exchange (NSE) declared three members as defaulters after they failed to meet their obligations.
Traders say a recent slump in stock prices, triggered by dismal first half company results and grim prospects, saddled market players with huge losses.
The benchmark 30-share BSE index has plummeted about 33 percent from its year's peak in June to three year lows.
On Tuesday, the index finished 16.49 points, or 0.59 percent, lower at 2,798.57.
